subject: RE: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?
msgSnippet: In the JUnit web page, there is a TesCase generators section where you can ... WTTOOLS JUnit Test Generator Lets assume you started developing your
messageBody:
In the JUnit web page, there is a "TesCase generators" section where you can
read:

--------------------------------------------
WTTOOLS JUnit Test Generator

Lets assume you started developing your application some weeks ago or some
months ago or even some years ago. I am sure that testing your code was one
of major problems. You thought about automating such process. And than you
heard about Unit Testing. So you would like to start use it. However how to
introduce Unit Testing for large number of source files. There is too much
of stupid code to write in all places again. That is where this package
comes in.

JUnit Test Generator

This code was created for the purpose of helping the QA team at Webmind inc.
in testing the projects being created in JAVA. It helps in creating Unit
Tests for the classes.

--------------------------------------------

I am not aware about those products.
Hope that will help you.

sylv1

PS: for your last question about to know why this kind of tools won't exist,
the reason i can imagine is that in a full XP spirit, you have to test
*before* coding. Your test code could not then be generated from your
development code. The contrary maybe ;o)


> -----Original Message-----
> From:
> sentto-2423328-4378-1016208697-sf=gatonero.com@...
> [mailto:sentto-2423328-4378-1016208697-sf=gatonero.com@...
> hoo.com]On Behalf Of markus baumgartner
> Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 5:14 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?
>
>
>
> I'm spending a lot of time passing new method into the testclass
> and write a
> "test_" in front of it (and oftenly forget to do it, too).
> I made a try to automate the creation of stubs for all existing
> methods of a
> class using the Reflection API (e.g. from myProcedure(int A, String B) to
> test_myProcedure_int_A_String_B. The final goal would be to have the tool
> comparing the class to the test_class and create stubs for new methods
> while leaving the existing ones untouched.
>
> Before I'm going to create it on my own, I wanted to know, if
> anybody knows
> about an existing tool, that does the job?
>
> If it does not exist, is there a good reason, why this automation wouldn't
> make sense? Sometimes for complex function you may need several testcases,
> but they can be easely created by taking the first stub and append a
> number...
>
>
>
>
>
